title: Pedagogical Content Knowledge in Science, Technology and the Environment
description: This course aims at helping students to acquire pedagogical content knowledge in the Area of “Science, Technology and the Environment”. It enables students to acquire a deeper understanding of subject knowledge in this specific Area of Study, think about subject knowledge from the students’ perspectives, apply subject knowledge from the perspective of multidisciplinary teaching, and organize instructional strategies of issue-based teaching in relevant conceptual and contextual considerations.The focus will be placed on understanding the scientific and technological principles and social implications of “Public Health and Technology” and “Energy and the Environment”. Students will be guided to apply relevant subject knowledge and skills in these areas to discuss and enquire into various related issues in order to reach evidence-based judgment and decisions. The implications of the processes and the results from these enquiries on the learning and teaching of Liberal Studies will be fully discussed.
outcome: By the end of the course, participants will be able to: 1. understand the aims and objectives of modules 5 and 6 in the Liberal Studies curriculum; 2. understand the scientific and technological principles and social implications of “Public Health and Technology” and “Energy and the Environment”; 3. design appropriate instructional strategies for facilitating pupils’ effective learning in modules 5 and 6; 4. plan lessons in modules 5 and 6 with issue enquiry approach 5. examine the issues inherent in the teaching and learning of public health and environmental issues in Liberal Studies.
syllabus: - Liberal studies –What are its values as a compulsory subject in senior secondary? What are the problems, difficulties and issues around teaching LS?  - Assessment issues in LS - questions analysis of DSE paper - What constitutes the pedagogical content knowledge (PCK) for liberal studies? - Curriculum planning - unit plan, module plan and year plan - Curriculum framework of modules 5 and 6 - What is public health? - A history of understandings of disease and health - Reasoning about causation in health issues - A critical appraisal of health claims - Environmental problems and Environmental philosophy - Climate changes and related political issues - A framework of issue analysis - Issue analysis of public health and environmental issues - Teaching by issue enquiry approach I - Group presentation of analysis on environmental issues and public health issues - Teaching by issue enquiry approach II - Microteaching

title: Pedagogical Content Knowledge in Society and Culture
description: This course aims at helping students to acquire pedagogical content knowledge in the Area of “Society and Culture”. It enables students to acquire a deeper understanding of subject knowledge in this specific Area of Study, think about subject knowledge from the students’ perspectives, apply subject knowledge from the perspective of multidisciplinary teaching, and organize instructional strategies of issue-based teaching in relevant conceptual and contextual considerations.The Area of Study includes the following modules: Hong Kong Today, Modern China and Globalization. The focus of this course will be placed on enabling students to analyze the human conditions in certain social development and cultural contexts, with reference to their related subject knowledge and concepts from multi-disciplinary perspectives. In addition, issues-based teaching will be adopted to facilitate the students to reflect on the contradictions and values which have been embedded in various phenomena.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. understand the major concepts of Culture and Society; 2. identify the relevant pedagogical strategies in teaching the issues related to Hong Kong Today, Modern China and Globalization; 3. apply the appropriate concepts and pedagogical strategies to design the teaching plan with issue enquiry approach.
syllabus: 1. Introduction to Module 2, 3 and 4 of the LS curriculum  2. Teaching Hong Kong Today with issue enquiry approach  3. Teaching Modern China with issue enquiry approach  4. Teaching Globalization with issue enquiry approach  5. Teaching methods   (Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)

title: Foundations of Disciplinary Knowledge and General Education
description: This course aims to introduce the theoretical and pedagogical nature of Liberal Studies (LS) and its foundational knowledge to students. In the first part of the course, students will be provided an overview on the theoretical and pedagogical underpinnings of the subject, including the curriculum classification “integrated curriculum”; the guiding philosophical principles “constructivist and student-centered approaches”; and pedagogic practice “issue-enquiry approach.”.In the second part of the course, the liberal studies approach to knowledge and education will be applied to inquire into three areas of studies in the context of the twenty-first century. The areas are (1) self and personal development, (2) society and culture, and (3) science, technology and the environment. These three areas are basically in correspondence with the three areas of study stipulated in syllabus of the Liberal Studies in the Hong Kong senior-secondary curriculum. In each area, concepts and theories related to the areas of inquiry are introduced. It attempts to lay the pedagogical foundation for the teaching and learning of liberal studies in secondary schools in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

title: Liberal Studies and Methods of Inquiry
description: This course aims to help students understand the nature of Liberal Studies and its theoretical and pedagogical foundations. Various perspectives on Liberal Studies and different interpretations of its genesis and its significance will be explored. Issue-based inquiry and its variations will be introduced and examined. The conceptual and pedagogical features of various methods of inquiry, including conceptual, factual, valuative and critical, will be explicated using issues related to Liberal Studies curriculum in Hong Kong secondary schools.

title: Pedagogical Content Knowledge in Self and Personal Development
description: This course aims to facilitate students’ acquisition of the pedagogical content knowledge in the area of "Self and Personal Development". It enables students to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the subject knowledge in this specific area of study, think about subject knowledge from the learners' perspectives, apply subject knowledge from the perspective of multi-disciplinary teaching, and organize instructional strategies of issue-based teaching.The focus will be placed on understanding personal development and interpersonal relationships in the context of family, peers, and society. Pedagogical strategies like group discussion, debate, role-play, news analysis and independent-enquiry studies, etc. will be introduced to illustrate how the various issues in the module can be addressed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be able to: 1. gain an in-depth understanding of the concepts and theories in the area of Self and Personal Development, 2. identify various pedagogical strategies in addressing the issues related to the area of Self and Personal Development, and 3. apply relevant pedagogical strategies to the design of teaching materials that will facilitate learning and understanding of the various issues introduced in the course.

Media and socialization  10. Gender mainstreaming  (Please refer to the course outline of the respective teachers for details.)

title: Independent Enquiry Studies (I): Research Methods
description: This course aims to help students understand research process and common research methodology relevant to Independent Enquiry Studies (IES). It introduces student skills including: (a) develop research questions, (b) design a research plan to collect quantitative and/or qualitative data, (c) conduct basic statistical and qualitative data analyses and (d) interpret and discuss results. Students will carry out a group research project to consolidate these skills. These skills prepare students to conduct research projects independently.Assessment Criteria:Participation in Class Discussion & In-class Exercises (10%)Attendance & active participations are expected.Group project presentation (45%)Each group would conduct a 20-mins presentation and lead the following 10-mins Q&A section. 35% of the course assessment would be allocated to the group presentation, 5% would be marked on the basis of your constructive feedbacks or critical comments on others’ presentations during the Q&A sections, and another 5% would be given by your groupmates as peer-evaluation.Literature Review Assignment (45%)Each student is required to select a research paper from the group project reading and provide a critique with the following sections: • A brief and precise summary of the research background, objectives and the research design. [10%]• Critical comment on its strength and weakness. [12%]• What methodological and/or ethical issues would you like to raise for further discussion? [8%]• How does this research contribute to your group research project? [5%]• What further studies would you suggest? Please briefly describe and explain. [5%]• Format & Writing quality. [3% + 2%]

title: Principles of C&I in LS/Citizenship and Social Development I: Theories
description: This course examines the theoretical foundation of multidisciplinary and issue-based teaching in the context of curriculum development in Hong Kong. It discusses the pedagogy of issue-based learning, with reference to the design of school-based integrated humanities curriculum and the development of teaching materials for Liberal Studies/Citizenship and Social Development in senior secondary curriculum.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to  1. understand how integrated curriculum in Hong Kong are shaped by pedagogical innovations such as issue-based learning, and how it is different from conventional subjects which have strong academic traditions;  2. understand the possible options for and problems of curriculum mapping in the implementation of Liberal Studies/Citizenship and Social Development in Hong Kong;  3. understand the need to bridge the gap between school-based curriculum in junior secondary school and Liberal Studies/Citizenship and Social Development in senior secondary school from the perspective of assessment for learning;  4. reflect on previous experience of designing individual teaching package and reach a deeper understanding of assessment criteria for effective classroom teaching

title: Principles of C&I in LS/Citizenship and Social Development III: Class Experience & Reflection
description: This course uses both case method and narrative method to afford student-teachers the opportunity to reflect on their own classroom experiences from teaching practice. It involves student-teachers in the formation of teacher knowledge, with particular connections to personal and professional development.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to 1. review classroom experience by using a case method which comprises four attributes: intention, chance, judgment and reflection;  2. revisit the nature of pedagogical content knowledge by using a narrative method which comprises four dimensions: practical experience, interpretation, reflection and transformation; 3. involve in case organization, case writing, case commentary and case conferences; 4. develop teacher knowledge through effective learning such as agency, reflection and collaboration.
syllabus: 1. A student who I remember most; Students’ feedback and evaluation at the end of TP; Teaching Practice Re-visited; Individual Teaching Portfolio.  2. Self Portrait and Critical events during TP  3. Marking experience: Issue-based cluster; Ability cluster; Question type cluster  4. Case writing: the attributes of a case are intention-chance-judgment-reflection (2000 words/2500 characters)  5. title: Principles of C&I in LS/Citizenship and Social Development IV: Instructional Design & Implementation
description: The course examines the stages of building an outstanding teaching portfolio, which documents a coherent story of the student-teacher as a reflective practitioner. It investigates the complex process of implementing an instructional design with particular reference to individual differences and assessment for learning.
outcome: By the end of the course, participants will be able to: 1. understand the stages of portfolio growth: an off-track portfolio, an emerging portfolio, an on-track portfolio and an outstanding portfolio;  2. review their own portfolio and become more aware of the stages of professional development; 3. develop critical thinking skills in content selection and lesson planning;  4. acquire skills in catering for individual differences and assessment for learning.

title: Independent Enquiry Studies II: Proposal and Project Report
description: This course aims to provide individual support for students to conduct an Independent Enquiry Studies. Each student will go through stages of research experience: proposal, literature review, data collection, data analysis and report writing.Assessment Criteria: Class participation, presentation and thesis writing
outcome: 1. Conduct literature review to support research questions 2. Develop plan for data collection 3. Analyze data and review research questions  4. Interpret data critically and discuss the findings 5. Evaluate quality of a proposal and a presentation 6. Develop problem solving skills
syllabus: 1. identify what research question they want to know more for their research project,  2. formulate a research topic using literature review, 3. develop a manageable research plan to collect data to answer their research questions,  4. analyze collected data critically and comprehensively, 5. Interpret and discuss the data with respect to other research findings, theories, and local relevance.

title: Independent Study I
description: Students will pursue independent study in selected topics and areas of Liberal Studies/Citizenship and Social Development under the supervision of a teacher as appointed by the board of the Faculty of Education. The contents of the course will depend on the original course to be substituted. Students are required to independently do the readings and complete the assignments stipulated by the teacher. Students and the teachers will meet regularly to discuss the progress of learning and the assignments. The workload and standards of the course is commensurate with the substitute course.
